Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for Young U.S. Career Scientists to the 6th International Conference on Atmosphere, Ocean and Climate Change; Hong Kong, China; August 19-21, 2013
Award.AbstractNarration: The travel support is for 10 early career scientist from the U.S to attend the 6th conference International Conference on Atmosphere, Ocean and Climate Change scheduled to be held in Hong Kong China, August 19-21, 2013. They will present scientific findings at the event. The early career scientists will be selected by the conference organization committee following an open call for applications. The conference theme is broad; the support will focus on topics dealing with regional problems in Asia-Pacific rim e.g. climate change, atmospheric physics and chemistry, extreme events. The conference will provide an excellent opportunity for the early career scientist to gain new ideas and knowledge from the talks and presentations, which would be helpful for their career development and scientific pursuits. This award is co-funded by NSF International Science and Engineering section, Office of International and Integrative Activities.

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This funding was used to support young scientists to attend the 6th International Conference on Atmosphere, Ocean and Climate Change held at Hong Kong, China on19-21 August 2013.

The conference aims to provide a forum and platform to (1) facilitate professional contacts and to enhance interactions for professionals in atmosphere-ocean-climate fields around the world with a focus on Asia-Pacific region; (2) to exchange and share knowledge on regional weather, climate and oceanographic studies; (3) to foster interactional collaborations in tackle with some outstanding problems unique to the region such as air pollution, monsoon, Tibet plateau, etc.  

Benefits of the funding include:

1. Allow the young investigators in US to attend this important international conference that bring many scientists from US and around the world, in particular the Asia.  They had a unique opportunty to learn about the environment and climate change studies conducted in this most populated yet fast developing region where emissions are so large that may affect the climat eof Pan America. Such a knowledge is very important to understand climate changes across the Pacific Rim. 

2. They had an unique opportunity to interact with and learn from leading researchers from both US and Asia to enhance their research aptitude and also promot the impact of their own reseach.

3. By presentating their preliminary findings, feedback and comments received help improve the quality of their follow on studies through peer-review journal publications. 

4. Several of their papers are likely published in a special section in J. Geophy. Res. concerning Asian pollution and climate following this conference.
